issue.title: jboss logmanager breaks exception logging
issue.body:
### Bug description

When a route has an expression like `header("foo")` and an error is thrown the following is attempted to be logged `header{foo}` which makes some formatter expect a number between the curly brackets.

```
from("timer:foo?period=1000")
        .setBody(header("foo"))
        .throwException(new IllegalStateException())
        .log("Hello World");
```

what's attempted to be logged

```
Failed delivery for (MessageId: ECD59AB66C216B6-0000000000000004 on ExchangeId: ECD59AB66C216B6-0000000000000004). Exhausted after delivery attempt: 1 caught: java.lang.IllegalStateException

Message History
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Source                                   ID                             Processor                                          Elapsed (ms)
Main:13                                  route1/route1                  from[timer://foo?period=1000]                                 1
Main:14                                  route1/setBody1                setBody[header{foo}]                                          0
Main:15                                  route1/throwException1         throwException[java.lang.IllegalStateException]               0

Stacktrace
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

{0}


```

Here's the output 
```

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: can't parse argument number: foo
        at java.base/java.text.MessageFormat.setFormatFromPattern(MessageFormat.java:1644)

        at org.jboss.logmanager.handlers.WriterHandler.doPublish(WriterHandler.java:54)
        at org.jboss.logmanager.ExtHandler.publish(ExtHandler.java:88)
        at io.quarkus.deployment.logging.LoggingResourceProcessor$1.accept(LoggingResourceProcessor.java:488)

        at org.jboss.logmanager.ExtFormatter.formatMessageLegacy(ExtFormatter.java:133)
```

from the reproducer [here](https://github.com/jam01/camel-log-repro/blob/main/src/main/java/com/acme/Main.java)

body: Having looked at https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues/45444 it seems those fixes both to quarkus 3.17 (now using 3.28) and logmanager 3.1.2 are not addressing the issue for Apache Camel. Still not quite sure of the issue stems from.

I had a look and I don't think it's an issue on our side.

You're passing an invalid message to the logging layer: you use message format to format your log messages and you have `{foo}`, which requires to pass `foo` as a parameter to message format.

What surprises me is that it looks like you don't use parameter interpolation and just build a massive string? Or am I mistaken?
If you used message interpolation and pass your message history as a parameter, I don't think you would have this problem.

> You're passing an invalid message to the logging layer: you use message format to format your log messages and you have `{foo}`, which requires to pass `foo` as a parameter to message format.

It's not really intended to be parameterized in this case. As per the example above, `setBody[constant{foo}]` is expected to be logged as-is. Which is what happens if you pass it to a standard SLF4J logger instance. Seemingly this also works ok in prod mode. It's only dev mode where you see the issue.

If we really can't fix it here, then I guess we'll have to handle it on the Camel side.

The workaround would be to use `LOG.infof()` which would instead use the `java.util.Formatter`. I don't think there is much we can do on the log manager side as `Hello {world}` is a `MessageFormatter` pattern.

I found why the problem only happens in dev mode. It's due to the [stack trace decorator](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/blob/c3944a942cbb1695f5c4d3a09a8d6d520d495fed/core/deployment/src/main/java/io/quarkus/deployment/logging/LoggingResourceProcessor.java#L423). When it's disabled, there are no issues.
@jamesnetherton no actually, I think the root of the issue is in the SLF4j log manager layer. Sorry, was busy this afternoon and could only have a look now.
